metadata.title: Gender antagonism and class conflict: Exclusionary strategies of male trade unionists in nineteenth-century Britain

relevance.topic: Gender antagonism and class conflict in labor markets
relevance.relevance: The study explores the exclusionary strategies of male trade unionists in nineteenth-century Britain, highlighting the intersection of gender and class conflict in labor markets, which is relevant to understanding labor displacement due to technological change.

independent_variables: introduction of women into traditionally male jobs

dependent_variables.displaced: Male workers in various industries were displaced by the introduction of women into their jobs.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: Male workers faced unemployment or had to seek work in other sectors after being displaced by women.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: Women were paid significantly lower wages than men for the same work, leading to wage suppression.

text_fragments: 'Rivals of Men! Why should they be rivals? Why not co-workers?'
'Men do not strike against their fellow workmen when the fields of labour become overfilled; why in the name of right and justice do they strike against women?'
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes how male trade unionists in nineteenth-century Britain employed exclusionary strategies to prevent women from entering certain trades, driven by a combination of gender antagonism and class conflict.

historical_context.economic_conditions: Industrial transformation and capitalist development in nineteenth-century Britain.
historical_context.institutional_context: Trade unions played a significant role in shaping labor market dynamics, often excluding women to protect male workers' interests.

outcomes.main_findings: The study finds that exclusionary strategies by male unionists were driven by a combination of class conflict and gender antagonism, with women being used as cheap labor by employers to undercut male workers.
outcomes.conclusions: Exclusionary strategies contributed to gender-segregated employment, which remains a feature of the labor market, benefiting capital by maintaining pay differentials.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The study suggests that the exclusion of women from certain trades contributed to long-term gender segregation in the labor market.
